The managers of the Metropolitan line had a vested interest in this as they also owned a very active real estate development company. The obvious conflict of interest was a specialty of the Metropolitan because it was the only company who was allowed to buy and keep land wholesale; Parliament forced all subsequent train companies to own only the land needed to built the tracks.

The station was rebuilt in 1939 and Charles Holden was again the designer. His style had changed slightly since Rayners Lane seven years earlier and he combines here his signature brick geometry and the very large glass window with lovely rounded pavilions on either side of the station porch. Rounded ends to buildings had become extremely popular in order to break the somewhat boring straight lines of pure Art Déco; they were also supposed to remind people of ocean liners and plane cockpits. There is actually a rounded end in Rayners Lane as well but it is much less conspicuous.

You might notice here that the station parade looks much more traditional than in Rayners Lane. It is just a plain row of identical houses, the only unusual detail being the balcony running all the way from one end of the parade to the other. It is actually not a balcony but the normal access corridor for the flats. This was quite common for council estates but is a bit strange along a main road.

After crossing the tracks L Elm Avenue

R Lime Grove

Soon after crossing Myrtle Road L into Warrender Park

Keep to the left edge of the park (or go back there after walking around)

Warrender Park is an other one of the planned parks set by the developer at regular distances. Like the other neighbourhood parks, it has much grass and a few lines of trees around the perimeter. There are two small beds with rose bushes near the entrance; like in Cavendish Recreation Ground, they look a bit scraggly.

At the end of the park, turn L and cross Myrtle Road into a public footpath . The footpath starts where Myrtle Road meets The Uplands (the continuation of the same road actually but there are clear signs)

Ignore the first road you cross. On reaching the second road, R Park Way (do not cross the tracks)

There is a pleasant strip of greenery along most of Park Way until you reach a row of shops

If you have a bit of time left, you can continue ahead on Pembroke Road for a short distance. This gives you an opportunity to see the local Roman Catholic church. It is not spectacular but is worth comparing with the church you saw at the start of the walk in Harrow. Here, the style is clearly reminiscent of medieval Italian cloisters with a low, squat basilica. This is actually the style Roman Catholics found more appropriate in general, partly because it stressed the link with the Pope.

Nearly opposite the church, there is a small but well maintained recreation ground with box hedges and flower beds. Once you have enjoyed the place, come back to the traffic lights in order to go to the station. The station is on your right coming from the church, on your left if you did not go on the small detour

Take Victoria Road to reach

RUISLIP MANOR

The station opened in 1912 on the line built in 1904 but this was a bit premature as there was very little traffic until the 1930s.

Looking at the bricks and at the shapes, I think the station building is a design from the 1930s, when it started to make sense to have a fully fledged station. It has certainly been influenced by Charles Holden who was responsible for the whole network, but the architect did not enjoy much designing stations when tracks were on an embankment like here as the shapes of the building would be overshadowed by the massive bridge and embankment. As a result, the boxy shapes are subdued and there is no convenient place to put large windows.

Cross under the tracks

After the shopping parade R Shenley Avenue

Very soon R into Shenley Park

Turn L within the park as you are otherwise blocked by the tracks

Exit into Willow Grove

Shortly before the road turns L, take the marked public footpath R towards Ruislip station. I think you cannot access the station directly; you will have to climb the stairs at the end of the path and take the main road bridge over the tracks. The station is easy to see from the bridge.

RUISLIP

The station opened together with the train line in 1904.

The station building does not look at all like an Underground station and would feel perfectly appropriate on a suburban train line in the southern suburbs. It is indeed the original design from 1904 at a time when the Metropolitan operated more like a suburban railway who just happened to own an underground line in central London. The valance over the porch and the window surroundings are painted white, contrasting strikingly with the subdued grey brick walls. This was a very popular style in Edwardian times.

METROPOLITAN LINE WALK 3

WEMBLEY PARK walk to HARROW-ON-THE-HILL

2 1/2 hours

The Metropolitan Railway operated originally a train line between London main line termini. It decided to compete with long-distance train companies and built a train line between a new terminus at Baker Street and market towns like Harrow, Watford and Amersham. When the line opened in 1880, it was crossing rural areas and no stops were considered necessary between London and Harrow. Intermediary stops were created later for the Metropolitan line, turning it into a suburban service, while a long-distance company continues to use the tracks without stops between its London terminus (Marylebone, close to Baker Street) and Harrow.

Routing note: This route connects at Wembley Park with Metropolitan line walk 2 and with Jubilee line walk 3. It connects in Harrow with Metropolitan line walks 4 and 6.

WEMBLEY PARK

There was no stop here when the line was opened in 1880 between London and Harrow. The Underground station opened in 1894 when an amusement park was built here by the chairman of the company as a separate commercial venture (therefore “park”). The grounds were re-used in 1924 for the British Empire Exhibition and are now the core of the stadium precinct. An additional branch opened in 1932 towards Stanmore (now the Jubilee line).

The original station building was replaced in the 1940s by a new structure because of the increasing traffic expected for the 1948 London Olympics. The station building is a plain brick building with just two small gables showing the train company logo. This was a style considered appropriate in the suburbs built in the 1930s, reminding more of a cottage than of a public building.

When Wembley Stadium was rebuilt and considerably extended in 2007, it was obvious that the old station building would not be able to accommodate the expected crowds and a new access was built. The glass and steel awning at the top of a particularly grand staircase was designed in a style reminding of the stadium with a lattice of thin steel tubes painted white.

Take the station exit on Bridge Road (not the main exit towards Wembley Stadium)

L on Bridge Road

Ahead Barn Hill

Barn Hill is a very good example of the suburban developments of the 1920s advertised as Metroland. Being the first suburban railway company authorised by Parliament, the Metropolitan Railway had managed to insert a clause that it was allowed to retain the land it did not need directly for the line construction. When the booming economy drew many people into the London suburbs after World War I, the company decided to develop the land it had kept idle for half a century. Technically, the developer was an independent company, but the owners and managers were the same.

Targeting the lower middle class that was looking for houses with gardens that could be financed with the growing availability of reasonably cheap mortgages, the company advertised heavily for new suburbs, extolling the quiet, the greenery, the clean air and the nostalgic details on the houses such as decorative wooden beams (the “mock-Tudor” style). This was extremely successful. You get a very good feeling for the typical Metroland suburb in the middle section of Barn Hill with identical, prim houses. In the upper section, the houses are larger and the road becomes a narrow lane lined with trees, which is a more upmarket version.

The Metroland suburbs were criticised heavily after World War II for having empty streets and no sense of community. Indeed, the boroughs were left with awkward plots for public buildings away from the core of the developments and very few parks were provided as all houses had gardens. In addition, residents had to walk long distances to shops and stations with bus services being difficult to organise due to the street layout so that using a car became unavoidable and made life less convenient than planned for commuters.

At the end ahead on a public footpath across Barn Hill Open Space, passing a pond at the top of the hill

This is the only large open space in a large portion of Metroland. It was a farm until it was bought in 1927 in order to prevent development. The railway had not been able to buy it because it really could not argue that it might need this land for the construction of the line. Like other hilltops in London, it was an important site in antiquity and there is evidence that some of the paths date back to Saxon times. Barn Hill is set apart from most hilltops in that it has a pond on the summit, a rather illogical occurrence.

Ahead down the hill towards the footbridge over the tracks

You can see on my picture that the public footpath appears in a slightly different shade of green on the ground. This is due to the fact that trampled grass regenerates differently, with the ground being more packed and retaining humidity here (in some other cases, the path is more barren due to the packed ground draining water faster). The view north is over the core of Metroland towards wooded hills that mark the edge of London.

The path continues along a small open space and merges into May Lane

The open space on this side of the tracks is a small neighbourhood park used for sports.

At the end L The Mall (a road)

Ahead Preston Hill

Ahead down Woodcock Hill

L Silverholme Close

Ahead on the path across Tenterden Sports Grounds

This is again a neighbourhood sports grounds. It is located very close to an Underground station but was not developed in the 1920s. I guess the railway company intended first to keep it and develop it into valuable commercial properties at a later point in time, but it might also have been needed as reserve land in case the company would need additional technical facilities for the railway.

The path merges at the end into Preston Waye

At the end R Preston Road

PRESTON ROAD

The station opened in 1908 under the cumbersome name “Preston Road halt for Uxendon and Kenton”, the halt being necessary to serve sports facilities used in the 1908 London Olympics. Increasing real estate development justified keeping the station opened but the name was simplified.

The station access is surprising, it is just a porch within a suburban shopping parade from 1931. It is interesting to compare such a parade with shopping streets from the 1960s (shops with large glass windows reached by a pedestrian passage protected from cars) or the 1990s (individual big stores set in the middle of huge car parks). As people would have to buy groceries every day because they seldom had refrigerators, shops would be located conveniently at the exit of the Underground on the way home.

Just after crossing the tracks R into Grasmere Avenue

Soon L Longfield Avenue

Soon R Glendale Gardens

At the end L College Road

R Carlton Avenue

R into Preston Park Recreation Ground

The park is a typical neighbourhood park with sports facilities, grass and trees. The size of the park is quite typical for Metroland, with the developer planning such a park about every 2/3 mile. This shows that walking about 15 minutes to a place such as a shop, a school, a station or a park was considered normal. We have got much more comfortable, with many people using their cars if the walk is longer than 3 minutes.

Exit the park on the western side near the pavilion and the tennis courts

R Montpelier Rise

Soon L on a marked public footpath leading to Allonby Gardens

At the end R Windermere Avenue

The road passes a pub just near the station. In this case, there is no shopping parade near the station, just a pub. This is because it is a minor station added on an existing line; there is an other station with many convenience shops quite close nearby. The architecture of the pub is an interesting style rarely chosen for pubs. It has simple shapes and many windows, a typical Art Déco feature from the 1930s, but the gables in the Dutch Renaissance style are very unusual for that period. Pubs normally are built very differently, trying to attract customers with a touch of countryside nostalgy (flower pots, wooden beams, old signs) and to retain them inside by having few windows (you are therefore not aware that it is already much later than planned).

Soon L under the tracks using the underpass for South Kenton station. This is one of very few locations in London suburbs where two Underground lines cross without an interchange. Normally, lines were designed a little like a star radiating from central London in order to serve different suburbs and avoid unprofitable competition. This is also the reason why Underground lines were seldom allowed in areas already well served by existing trains. The Metropolitan Railway came away in this case with the argument that Harrow was badly served by the existing line (now the Bakerloo line).

The underpass leads to The Link

R Nathans Road

Enter Northwick Park and turn L keeping along the edge of the park

This flat area is part of the very large expanse of Northwick Park. This is former farm land bought by Harrow school in 1905 in order to prevent development in close vicinity of this particularly exclusive institution. The borough bought additional land in 1936 to add to the original park. It is not really a park, more a wide open space used for sports.

The path reaches soon a paved access road (The Fairway)

R towards the car park

Ahead on a track called Proyers Path

The track ends at the station

NORTHWICK PARK

The station opened in 1923 on the existing line under the name “Northwick Park & Kenton” and the name was shortened in 1937.

Because the station was built long after the tracks, it is squeezed between the tracks on the top of the embankment and the station building is actually a brick shed on the platform, reminding much more of a suburban train line than of London Underground. The access is very modest but looked a bit better originally before the windows on both sides of the entrance were bricked up.

Turn around, going back a few yards on Proyers Path

The path forks soon. Take the smaller path along the edge of the open space and the University building fence

This university campus belongs surprisingly to the University of Westminster, the main campus of which is located logically in the borough of Westminster. Actually not far from Euston train terminus, where it could be built on open land back in the 1840s. It was a polytechnic (an institution delivering a national degree, a little like French universities, rather than an institution having to rely on its stand-alone reputation) and became very quickly leading in scientific and engineering specialties. The Harrow campus was built much later for the media, arts and design courses. There is apparently a campus gallery showing contemporary art but I was not aware of it and it is difficult to reach from my route because of the fences.

After leaving the open space, turn R on the footpath between the University of Westminster and an hospital access road

The hospital was an important project that enabled the NHS to close an outdated site in Central London in 1970. By now, the buildings are clearly outdated and an inspection body found a large number of significant issues to criticise in 2016. The architecture is particularly ugly, reflecting the budget constraints at the time of construction.

At the end L Watford Road

Cross this dangerous road at the next traffic light. The start of the next public footpath is well signposted near the lights. Take the path across Harrow School Playing Fields (more precisely between Upper Redding Field and Ducker Fields)

You are starting here to cross a very special place. Harrow School is one of the most renowned, most exclusive and most expensive schools in Britain. It looks back proudly to being founded in 1572 and accepts only boys, dressing them in 19th century uniforms and expecting them to behave like public school boys – we had better not look too closely into the pranks and experiences the boys gather over the years, particularly at night in the boarding houses… The large size of the sports fields is partly due to the fact that education in Britain includes a lot of sports, but also specifically to the fact that the school has many boarders who need to be occupied in a sensible manner after normal school courses.

The track leads uphill towards the school buildings. Ignore the car parks and turn R a little later into marked “public footpath no. 59 to Peterborough Road”, called also Music Hill

The path turns into a minor road further up the hill, this is now Football Lane

The school built many independent buildings over the year and is one of few schools of such standing that cannot prevent you from walking across the grounds due to the numerous public footpaths towards the parish church. I was interested by the sculpture that stands on your left while you climb Football Lane. The standing stones remind a lot of megalithic sites.

Opposite the standing stones, the small building with a large stained glass window framed by a neo-classical design is obviously devoted to arts. It must be a 19th century pavilion and imitates Italian Renaissance palaces with roundels depicting celebrities. The buildings were obviously built over time in contemporary fashion without paying much attention to the existing ones, but neo-gothic is overall the main style because the late 19th century was the heyday of public schools in terms of financial resources.

At the end L further uphill, walking past a chapel and ornate stairs

From the crossroads, you can enter the front garden of the most elegant building of the school, the Old Speech Room built in 1821 and extended in 1876. Part of the complex houses a collection of items of museum quality but I don’t think you can visit this unless by special appointment. The collection is primarily used for teaching purposes.

Another part of the building is a very grand Victorian hall used to train students to hold speeches – a sensible idea if many of your pupils can be expected to be Members of Parliament and influential businessmen later on. From outside, the building is not really neo-gothic and the style is closer to that of Elizabethan manors, trying to connect with the times when the school was founded.

The garden around the hall is very well kept as the school can afford professional gardeners. The most interesting item is a fountain with brass boulders. I have not checked whether these ones can actually turn; there was a fashion for a time in the 1980s with large boulder fountains, the water making it possible to move the boulder. The scheme became less popular later on due to the cost of pumping water. There might also have been issues with children climbing on the boulder, slipping and potentially getting hurt.

After the stairs R up Church Hill

L through the lychgate in order to reach the church

The parish church of St Mary’s is one of the most venerable churches in the London suburbs and lies in a privileged location in a wooded churchyard at the top of the hill.

The view extends up to 15 miles towards Canary Wharf, Crystal Palace and Windsor although it is usually easier to identify Heathrow Airport.

Some of the walls go back to the 13th century
